content.title: Warfarin Therapy
content.summary: Warfarin is an oral vitamin K antagonist (VKA) anticoagulant that inhibits synthesis of functional vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X) and anticoagulant proteins (protein C, S). It has a narrow therapeutic index, numerous drug and food interactions, and requires regular INR monitoring. Target INR is 2.0-3.0 for most indications and 2.5-3.5 for mechanical heart valves. While largely replaced by DOACs for many indications, warfarin remains essential for mechanical valves, antiphospholipid syndrome, and severe renal impairment.
key_points: Mechanism: Inhibits VKORC1 → blocks vitamin K-dependent factor synthesis
Onset: 5-7 days for full effect (factor II half-life ~60 hours)
Reversal: Vitamin K (slow), FFP/PCC (rapid), 4-factor PCC preferred
Many drug interactions (CYP2C9, CYP3A4, vitamin K content)
Bridge with heparin when starting - early protein C drop may cause hypercoagulability
content.statement: Warfarin is a vitamin K antagonist anticoagulant requiring INR monitoring, with target 2.0-3.0 for most indications, numerous drug and food interactions, and reversal options including vitamin K and prothrombin complex concentrate.

explanation.intuition: Warfarin works by 'starving' the liver of functional vitamin K, preventing proper clotting factor production. It takes days to work because existing clotting factors must die off first. Factor VII goes first (6 hours), but factor II (prothrombin) lasts 60 hours - that's why full anticoagulation takes a week.
explanation.key_insight: Protein C (anticoagulant) has a shorter half-life than prothrombin (procoagulant). When starting warfarin, protein C drops before factor II, creating a transient hypercoagulable state. This is why we bridge with heparin and why warfarin alone can cause skin necrosis in protein C deficiency.
explanation.technical_details: Warfarin inhibits VKORC1 (vitamin K epoxide reductase), preventing recycling of vitamin K to its reduced active form. Metabolism primarily via CYP2C9 (major) and CYP3A4 (minor). S-warfarin is 3-5× more potent than R-warfarin. VKORC1 and CYP2C9 genetic polymorphisms affect dosing. Half-life 20-60 hours; peak effect 36-72 hours.

definitions_glossary.warfarin: Oral vitamin K antagonist anticoagulant inhibiting VKORC1
definitions_glossary.VKORC1: Vitamin K epoxide reductase complex 1; warfarin's molecular target
definitions_glossary.INR: International Normalized Ratio; standardized PT measurement for warfarin monitoring
definitions_glossary.vitamin_K_antagonist: Drug class blocking vitamin K-dependent factor synthesis
definitions_glossary.therapeutic_index: Ratio of toxic to therapeutic dose; narrow for warfarin
definitions_glossary.bridging_anticoagulation: Temporary use of heparin when starting/stopping warfarin
definitions_glossary.PCC: Prothrombin complex concentrate; contains II, VII, IX, X for rapid reversal
definitions_glossary.protein_C: Vitamin K-dependent anticoagulant; early drop causes hypercoagulability
definitions_glossary.supratherapeutic_INR: INR above target range; increased bleeding risk
definitions_glossary.warfarin_skin_necrosis: Rare complication from protein C depletion; more common in protein C deficiency
definitions_glossary.time_in_therapeutic_range: TTR; quality measure for warfarin management

mechanism.effect: Blocks vitamin K recycling → reduced γ-carboxylation

pharmacokinetics.onset: 24-72 hours INR rise; 5-7 days full anticoagulation

genetics.clinical_use: Pharmacogenetic dosing can reduce adverse events

alternative_to_DOACs.atrial_fibrillation: When DOACs contraindicated or not tolerated
alternative_to_DOACs.VTE: Alternative when cost or access is barrier

initiation.typical_start: 5 mg daily (2.5 mg if elderly, low weight, liver disease)
initiation.bridging: Concurrent heparin/LMWH until INR therapeutic × 24 hours

monitoring_frequency.initial: Daily or every other day until stable

decreased_INR.vitamin_K_sources: High intake of green leafy vegetables

dietary.advice: Maintain consistent intake rather than avoiding

skin_necrosis.mechanism: Protein C depletion before factor II depletion
skin_necrosis.risk_factors: Protein C or S deficiency; loading doses
skin_necrosis.prevention: Bridge with heparin; avoid loading doses

adverse_effects.teratogenicity: Warfarin embryopathy; avoid in pregnancy (especially weeks 6-12)

non_urgent.oral_vitamin_K: 1-2.5 mg if INR very high or higher risk patient

reversal_agents_comparison.4F_PCC: Fast, small volume, preferred for major bleeding

definition.@value: Oral anticoagulation using vitamin K antagonist warfarin, requiring INR monitoring and dose adjustment

scopeNote.@value: Essential for mechanical valves and antiphospholipid syndrome

learning_objectives: Explain warfarin's mechanism of action via VKORC1 inhibition
Select appropriate INR target for different indications
Identify major drug and food interactions
Manage supratherapeutic INR with appropriate reversal strategy
Recognize warfarin skin necrosis risk in protein C deficiency
clinical_pearls: Full anticoagulation takes 5-7 days - factor II half-life is 60 hours
Bridge with heparin: protein C drops before factor II → transient hypercoagulability
Target 2.5-3.5 for mechanical valves; 2.0-3.0 for everything else
4-factor PCC preferred over FFP for major bleeding reversal
Maintain consistent vitamin K intake - don't need to avoid greens
common_misconceptions: Warfarin works immediately - takes 5-7 days for full effect
Avoid all vitamin K foods - just maintain consistent intake
Loading doses speed anticoagulation safely - they increase bleeding and necrosis risk
FFP is best for reversal - 4-factor PCC is preferred
